While there were some individuals and groups within European countries who advocated for a more humanitarian approach to colonization in Africa, such as missionaries and philanthropists, the overall objective of European colonization was to exploit Africa's resources and to expand their empires. 

However, there were some instances where European powers implemented policies that were aimed at promoting social and economic development in Africa. For example, the British colonial government in Nigeria established the Department of Agriculture in 1912 to promote farming and improve agricultural productivity. Additionally, the French government established schools and hospitals in their colonies in West Africa to provide education and healthcare to local populations.

Nonetheless, these policies were often implemented with the objective of promoting economic development and maintaining political control over the colonized territories, rather than uplifting the lives of the African people. Furthermore, these policies were often discriminatory and exploited local communities, further contributing to the exploitation and oppression of Africans during the colonial era.
